candidates.name: John Cornyn
candidates.summary: Four-term incumbent, former TX Attorney General and TX Supreme Court Justice. Senate's second-ranking Republican. Legislative dealmaker who secured CHIPS Act manufacturing investments for Texas.
candidates.background: Served as Texas Attorney General (1999–2002) and on the Texas Supreme Court. In the U.S. Senate since 2002. Former Majority Whip.
pros: Massive spending advantage ($59M in allied spending)
cons: Supported some bipartisan bills that angered the base

candidates.name: Ken Paxton
candidates.summary: Current Texas Attorney General. Impeached by the TX House in 2023, acquitted by Senate. Under federal indictment for securities fraud. Leads primary polling.
candidates.background: Texas Attorney General since 2015. Impeached by the Texas House, acquitted by Senate. Under federal indictment for securities fraud since 2015.
cons: Impeached by his own party's House
Staff reported him to FBI for bribery

candidates.name: Wesley Hunt
candidates.summary: U.S. Representative, West Point graduate, Apache helicopter combat pilot. Triple Ivy League degrees. Young, dynamic next-generation candidate.
candidates.background: U.S. Army combat veteran (Apache helicopter pilot). West Point graduate. MBA and MPA from Ivy League schools. Elected to Congress in 2022.
cons: Only 17% in polls — splits anti-Paxton vote

recommendation.reasoning: Effective, experienced legislator with real deliverables for Texas. If stopping the indicted frontrunner matters to you, Cornyn is the only viable vehicle — Hunt splits the opposition vote at 17%.
recommendation.strategicNotes: A runoff between the top two is almost certain. Every opposition vote for Cornyn helps ensure he makes the runoff in the strongest position.
recommendation.caveats: Career politician, which frustrates some voters. But the alternative has serious legal and ethical issues.

candidates.name: Chip Roy
candidates.summary: U.S. Representative and former First Assistant AG under Paxton. Federal prosecutor background. Constitutional conservative who resigned from AG's office on principle. Frontrunner at 33-40%.
candidates.background: Currently serving in Congress (TX-21). Served as First Assistant Attorney General. Former Assistant U.S. Attorney prosecuting violent criminals.
pros: Actually served in the AG's office
Resigned on principle from Paxton's AG office
cons: Some may see him as establishment

candidates.name: Mayes Middleton
candidates.summary: State Senator and businessman. Chair of the Texas Freedom Caucus. Positioned as the most conservative option.
candidates.background: Texas State Senator. Chairman of the Texas Freedom Caucus. Oil and gas businessman.
cons: Freedom Caucus approach can be combative

candidates.name: Joan Huffman
candidates.summary: State Senator with prosecutorial background. Over 100 jury trials. Led the Paxton impeachment trial as presiding judge.
candidates.background: Texas State Senator. Former prosecutor with over 100 jury trials. Presided over the Paxton impeachment trial in the Senate.
pros: Presided over impeachment — understands the office
cons: May not be viable in a crowded field

candidates.name: Aaron Reitz
candidates.summary: Deputy Secretary of State under Governor Abbott. Youngest candidate in the race. Self-funded with $12M.
candidates.background: Former Deputy Secretary of State. Attorney.

recommendation.reasoning: Best combination of legal experience and principled conservatism. Actually served in the AG's office and resigned on principle. Federal prosecutor background gives him credibility for the role.
recommendation.strategicNotes: Roy needs 50% to avoid a runoff. Consolidating behind the frontrunner helps avoid a prolonged primary.

candidates.name: Kelly Hancock
candidates.summary: Appointed Comptroller after Glenn Hegar resigned. Former state senator with 10 years on the Senate Finance Committee. Authored the state spending cap.
candidates.background: Former state senator. Served on Legislative Budget Board. Appointed Acting Comptroller.
cons: Insider appointment — didn't win the seat in an election

candidates.name: Don Huffines
candidates.summary: 'DOGE Texas' platform — government efficiency. Former state senator and real estate developer. Best-funded candidate at $15.8M (mostly self-funded). Lost 2022 governor's race.
candidates.background: Former state senator. Real estate developer. Lost the 2022 governor's primary to Abbott.
pros: DOGE platform resonates with efficiency voters
cons: Family real estate dealings raised questions

candidates.name: Christi Craddick
candidates.summary: 12+ years as Railroad Commissioner (state energy regulator). Won statewide three times. Father is former TX House Speaker Tom Craddick.
candidates.background: Current Railroad Commissioner since 2012. Attorney. Father is longest-serving Texas state legislator.
cons: $20M+ in industry lease interests while regulating that industry

candidates.name: Michael Berlanga
candidates.summary: Lesser-known candidate in the Comptroller race.

recommendation.reasoning: Most relevant fiscal experience — 10 years on Senate Finance, authored the spending cap, currently doing the job. Clean record with no conflicts of interest.
recommendation.strategicNotes: At only 13%, Hancock may not be viable. If stopping Huffines is the priority, Craddick at 21% is the strategic alternative.
recommendation.caveats: Insider appointment feels like backroom dealing. If strategic viability matters more, consider Craddick.

candidates.name: Nate Sheets
candidates.summary: Entrepreneur who built a specialty food company from a backyard operation into a national brand. Navy veteran. Governor Abbott endorsed him over the incumbent — a rare rebuke.
candidates.background: Founded a successful food company. U.S. Navy veteran. Entrepreneur.
keyPositions: Refocus office on actual farming mission
endorsements: Gov. Greg Abbott (endorsed over his own party's incumbent)
pros: Built a real business in the food industry

candidates.name: Sid Miller
candidates.summary: Scandal-plagued incumbent. State investigators looking into his office. Aide indicted for bribery. Known more for culture war social media posts than agricultural policy.
candidates.background: Commissioner of Agriculture since 2015. Former state representative. Rodeo competitor.
cons: Lost thousands of farmers from state programs on his watch
Office focused on culture war, not agriculture

recommendation.reasoning: Entrepreneur vs. scandal-plagued incumbent. Governor Abbott himself broke ranks to endorse Sheets — that's how problematic Miller's tenure has been. Sheets would refocus the office on actual agriculture.

candidates.name: Greg Abbott
candidates.summary: Three-term incumbent with $106M war chest. No credible primary challenger among 10 opponents.
candidates.background: Governor since 2015. Former Attorney General (2002-2015). Former Texas Supreme Court Justice.
pros: Incumbent with strong GOP base support
cons: Grid failures under his watch (2021 winter storm)
Some conservatives feel he's not aggressive enough

candidates.name: Dan Patrick
candidates.summary: Three-term incumbent with $33.5M. Presides over the Texas Senate. No credible challenger.
candidates.background: Lt. Governor since 2015. Former state senator and conservative radio host. Presides over the Texas Senate.
pros: Effectively controls the Texas Senate agenda
cons: More culture warrior than some prefer

candidates.name: Jim Wright
candidates.summary: Incumbent Railroad Commissioner. Oil field services business owner and fifth-generation Texas rancher. Emphasizes fair and consistent energy regulation.
candidates.background: Oil field services business owner. Fifth-generation Texas rancher. Railroad Commissioner since 2020.
cons: Industry insider — potential conflicts of interest

candidates.name: Katherine Culbert
candidates.summary: Challenger in the Railroad Commissioner race.

recommendation.reasoning: Competent incumbent with relevant industry experience. None of his challengers have made a compelling case for change.

candidates.name: Ge'Nell Gary
candidates.summary: Republican candidate in the heavily Democratic Austin-centered CD-37.
cons: D+26 district — Republican nominee will lose in November

candidates.name: Lauren B. Pena
candidates.summary: Republican candidate in CD-37.
cons: D+26 district — Republican nominee will lose in November

candidates.name: Janet Malzahn
candidates.summary: Republican candidate in CD-37.
cons: D+26 district — Republican nominee will lose in November

recommendation.reasoning: In a symbolic race (D+26 district), this vote is about expression rather than outcome. The Republican nominee will not win in November.
recommendation.strategicNotes: The real action in CD-37 is in the Democratic primary.
recommendation.caveats: Limited information available about all three candidates.

candidates.name: Chris Gober
candidates.summary: Election law attorney. Considered one of the top contenders in the crowded 9-candidate field for McCaul's open seat.
candidates.background: Attorney specializing in election law. Well-connected in Republican politics.

candidates.name: Jessica Karlsruher
candidates.summary: Candidate in the CD-10 open seat race.

candidates.name: Rob Altman
candidates.summary: Candidate in the CD-10 open seat race.

recommendation.reasoning: Open seat with 9 candidates — one of the most competitive Republican primaries in the Austin area. A runoff is very likely given the crowded field.
recommendation.strategicNotes: With 9 candidates, no one is likely to hit 50%. Expect a runoff between the top two.
recommendation.caveats: Limited polling and public information available for many candidates in this race.

candidates.name: Gupta
candidates.summary: Sole Republican candidate for House District 48.

propositions.title: Phase out property taxes
propositions.description: Texas property taxes should be assessed at the purchase price and phased out entirely over the next six years through spending reductions.
propositions.reasoning: Aspirational but popular. Signals strong support for property tax relief.

propositions.title: Voter approval for local tax hikes
propositions.description: Texas should require any local government budget that raises property taxes to be approved by voters at a November general election.
propositions.reasoning: Direct accountability mechanism for local government spending.

propositions.title: Healthcare & vaccination status
propositions.description: Texas should prohibit denial of healthcare or any medical service based solely on the patient's vaccination status.
propositions.reasoning: Medical freedom issue. Not directly related to most voters' top priorities.

propositions.title: Life at fertilization in schools
propositions.description: Texas should require its public schools to teach that life begins at fertilization.
propositions.reasoning: Social conservative priority. Depends on your views on school curriculum.

propositions.title: Ban school health clinics
propositions.description: Texas should ban gender, sexuality, and reproductive clinics and services in K-12 schools.
propositions.reasoning: Social conservative priority. Depends on your views on school health services.

propositions.title: Term limits
propositions.description: Texas should enact term limits on all elected officials.
propositions.reasoning: Broadly popular across the political spectrum. Limits entrenchment of career politicians.

propositions.title: Protect Texas water
propositions.description: Texas should ban the large-scale export, or sale, of our groundwater and surface water to any single private or public entity.
propositions.reasoning: Water security is a growing Texas concern. Protects a critical resource.

propositions.title: End services for undocumented immigrants
propositions.description: The Texas Legislature should reduce the burden of illegal immigration on taxpayers by ending public services for illegal immigrants.
propositions.reasoning: Depends on how broadly you define 'public services' and your immigration views.

propositions.title: No Democratic committee chairs
propositions.description: The Republican-controlled Texas Legislature should stop awarding leadership positions, including committee chairmanships, to Democrats.
propositions.reasoning: Hyper-partisan. Cross-aisle governance and bipartisan committee work have long Texas traditions.

propositions.title: Prohibit Sharia Law
propositions.reasoning: Foreign religious law has no legal standing in Texas courts already. Purely symbolic.
